content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Right off the bat i have to say the obvious thing, I loved this game because it's so similar to dark souls 1; but just beacause is so similar doesn't mean is a clone; S&S takes all the right things from the dark souls formula (no map, punishing difficulty, several classes) and adds it's own ideas to it.Some of the differences are that:- Salt (souls) is different than money, you only lose some money when you die, but all of your salt is stolen from the enemy that killed you, to retrieve the salt you have to slay the enemy (who is stronger because of the salt). - Sanctuaries (Bonefires) come in two kinds, those who only heal you and reset enemies and those which let you level up and summon merchants, for the second type of sanctuary you have to choose a covenant which affects different things like how your "estus" work.- The level up system come in two parts, when you level up you spend your salt and that increases some stats, but when you level up you also get a "skill" item which you can spend immediately or whenever you want which increases specifically one stat; this is great if you want to not risk your salt but do not want to actually level up yet.The gameplay mechanics and atmosphere feels and play like dark souls 1, the "soul" of the franchise is without a doubt there.Leaving aside the fact that this is a separate game from the soul series I literally think this is a way bettr sequel to dark souls 1 than dark souls 2 (which i disliked immensely), 10 out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
Product received for free
												Ska Studios originally made their mark on the video game scene with their Xbox 360 Live Arcade series, The Dishwasher which became a nigh-instant cult classic side-scrolling beat-em-up/hack-and-slash a la goldenaxe, double dragon, etc.a friend of mine was very hyped about those games and got one of them at least, on his xbox 360 and i got to watch him play the brutal carnage-filled work of art. it was interesting, to say the least.however, Steam's indie release friendliness has proven far more fruitful for newer developers and quite honestly i'm glad that the company has decided to bring what will probably be their biggest title for a long time, to steam, as well as many other platforms (including the vita apparently).Salt and Sanctuary is a strange metroid-vania beat-em-up/platform/hack-and-slash side-scroller hybrid that takes the best of Ska's original Dishwasher series in terms of stylization and function, and mixes it with features from the most popular of brutal, unforgiving hack-and-slashers to-date: the Dark Souls franchise. this is no mere 'souls clone', and although it may not be for everyone, it is a gem of a game that i don't see getting one-upped for awhile.you play as a shipwrecked survivor (whom you design a bit, yourself) who was originally enlisted to protect someone and after a bad night on the seas... have lost track of that person... and you have also been shipwrecked in a strange land, seemingly overburdened with undead and bandits... and giant bearwolf things... yeah...so here's the breakdown: if you like metroidvanias, especially dark, grotesque, atmospheric artsy-ish games, you may want to give this one a look. if you like darksouls and don't mind side-scroll platforming, you should probably check this out. if you grew up with some of the craziest nes, snes and sega genesis games out there like double dragon, golden axe, battletoads, and so many more beat-em-up platformers, you may enjoy this title as well. so here's the scores1) GRAPHICS- 9/10the graphics are the most artistic thing about this title, and what sets it apart from other games. it has similarities to ska's other hit series the dishwasher, but it is not a clone of that in terms of style or details. it's kind of its own thing. and it does what it does quite well. my only gripe is that sometimes i don't see an enemy until i'm walking into it and then... i'm getting clawed at ._. but these visuals are stunning to say the least.2) SOUND EFFECTS/MUSIC- 10/10I havent let the music set in too much yet or had it up very loud but it really does paint the atmosphere nicely when it's there. it feels retro at times but has a modern-tech sound as well so that it doesn't just chiptune you to death while you're trying to emmerse yourself. it fits the game well. a more pixelated game may have benefitted from a more cartoonish or chiptunish soundtrack but this game has what it needs for sounds and you'll not have much of a gripe here yourself, i am sure.3) STORYLINE- ??/10i like what i've found so far on the story but i'm REALLY not that far in and can't say much about it so i'm just going to leave it at... it's interesting, but in the same vein as the souls series, it's not extremely story-based so you don't learn a whole lot at first... possibly ever... but it's enough to be intriguing.4) GAMEPLAY- 9/10it's solid. i'm struggling to learn some of the weapons i've found and many seem a bit harder to wield than they should be, like the hitboxes are very specific and the area of your weapon closer to the hilt on a longer weapon won't hurt enemies it seems, but if you learn the hitbox area and timing you can typically do pretty well here. if you have a one handed weapon and a shield, or a two handed weapon, it seems blocking is a viable option, and a necessity. timing is everything here as well... it's also a bit too easy to get overwhelmed with enemies that 'spawn' behind you and in front, and some of which are hard to see until you're getting pounded by five to ten guys, some of which can do some harsh damage... ugh. but, as per the souls series, you drop your experience if you die once and have to go back for it- the twist is, the enemy who killed you takes it and you have to seek revenge to get it back. if you die while an enemy still has your experience, you lose what he had forever... ouch. this can be a bit unforgiving, and with the few clunky things this game has going against it, may turn some away, but if you are a souls fan at all you are used to this sort of grind. thankfully there doesnt seem to be a durability factor in this but i could be wrong. i hope i'm not, because although that worked in the souls games, i don't want it in this one.OVERALL- 9.5/10seriously, this game is pretty epic so far. i've heard you can get up to like 30 hours from one playthrough, which isn't bad for the price (and if you get it on sale that's a damn good amount of hours for one playthrough, and the game has definite replayability). if you like souls games, metroidanias, beat-em-ups, hack-and-slashers, horror-ish games, grindfests, gorefests, brutal, unforgiving (yet mostly fair) experiences, and/or indie games, you should check this out, for sure. maybe wait until a sale if you feel the price is too high for you or you're still unsure after reading reviews... but definitely look into it. i warn you though, sales don't seem to come often for this one... but it's new-ish, so that's to be expected.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												A challenging platform hack and slash rpg game inspired by dark souls. As the only survivor of a ship hijacking, you must journey through a mysterious island in order to find the princess you had been tasked to protect during your naval voyage.Salt and sanctuary offers a rich in lore world filled with tough enemies to tackle. Jump your way from platform to platform, discover secret doors, explore dark chasms, employ magic, prayers or many different types of weapons to take your enemies down. Develop your character by learning skills from the skill tree, mastering heavy armour and greatsword fighting, marksmanship employing primitive guns, crossbows or bows or mystical skills relating to magic or prayer. This way, you can customize your character completely to suit your individual style of play.And in line with typical ds games, be prepared to die, die and die some more;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29
												Hands down... my personal "Game of the Year 2016"Just recently came out on the PS Vita, therefore it is THE de facto, "One and Only" Dark Souls-like game on any handheld console.   I wouldnt try to compare this to the Castlevania games because S&S has its own character, or more accurately it is pretty much a Metrovania game with Dark Souls action RPG gameplay.  So, If you like Dark Souls + Castlevania, then you will love Salt and Sanctuary.Likes: The overall world level design is pretty interesting.The background/zone level designs are all unique and creative making your journey around the island feel less dull and repeative when you grind for levels and loot for crafting. There are lots of short cuts to open,lots of zones to explore, lots of bosses to fight, a nice variety of routes to certain bosses and certain collecting of "brands" aka key character abilities like in Metroid, so like in the first Dark Souls game its not completely full on linear progression, but rather it's linear with multiple branches. Ofcourse there are what I would call, "key PLOT bosses/zones" that are significant enough where YOU HAVE TO BEAT in order to progress.Also the Boss names/designs are REALLY REALLY COOL, enough said on that, and ofcourse there is LORE descriptions in thier item drops.Also just like in Dark Souls you can CUSTOMIZE the balls out of your character, so enough can be said about that for sure.One thing of note, the very first great sword you find is BROKEN (OP'd) as Hell, which makes going through your first playthrough fairly do-able, especially if you use poison builds.The travel system is pretty conveinant just like in Dark Souls and depending how well you utilize the "Make Offerings" feature at your "Sanctuaries/Shrines" which are your  NPC merchants/crafters/covenenant specific uses.Well I could on and on about how much I like S&S but its TOO LONG TO LIST lolDislikes:Sadly, the character art design is kinda bad.  It looks kinda cheap/lazy, and character features looks like those animated characters of that electro punk band Gorillaz, except Gorillaz looks WAY better.  I think this game's character creator is probably the worst part of this game which was unfortunately a turn off to some people who look down on indie games like this.However I do feel the equipment you pick later on kinda makes up for it, like the Bloodbrow set which is obviously a nice inspriational nod to Bloodborne including an NPC you meet who wears the set, and gives you lore about the "Bloodbrow Hunters" fighting "Beasts" lolIt's pretty sick looking, and there are also other good looking equip sets you can find or grind from enemies like the Split Swordsman.Bottom line the inital character designs are terrible, but you can find equipment that does look cool on your character.And speaking of equipment, ugh....the Inventory menu is kind of a lazy jankâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥mess. Don't be fooled upon first impression look of a "Souls-like" asethetic but whenever you pick up items/gear/weapons and etc. it is sorted in the order of what and when you picked up first.  THERE IS NO WAY TO ORGANIZE your inventory, except drop everything ONE BY ONE in the order you want it as.Yes, I know this is a very nit picky criticism but damn its annoying as hell for OCD guys like myself that wants my sets in a particularly place and order.As far as music, not a whole of lot variety, every boss has the same common boss music which is fine,  however this game did do the FINAL BOSS a huge justice by having its own unique music, even the map before the final boss has its own unique music which was really cool upen first visit.  And as you grind levels and loot through out the game you can occasionaly get those sick ambient heavy metal riffs which is something Dark Souls games doesnt have, so that is a nice touch.Last thing that I didnt like is some of the bullcrap platforming shenanigans in later levels like those platforms where they disappear after 2 3 seconds, and you have to time your self FOR EACH AND EVERY SINGLE disappearing platform, which was ANNOYING AS HELL,  and in some extreme places if you miss the platform YOU FALL TO YOUR DEATH. However I believe it was just one Zone where you had to deal with the bullcrap disappearing platform garbage, and it is beatable, not impossible but annoying as crap.Well that's my two cents, and I hope you guys enjoy this awesome game and for reading my insights, and ofcourse apologies to any spelling/grammar freaks for burning your OCD.  Cheers! :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Salt and Sanctuary is a fantastic mix of the best elements from games such as Metroid, Castlevania, and the critically acclaimed Dark Souls series. From the very beginning of the game, players are drawn in by the surprisingly deep combat system, as well as traditional RPG elements such as inventory management, gear upgrades and a sprawling skill tree. The magic/prayer system is as intuitive as it is innovative, and rewards players who invest in 'multiclassing' with a variety of buffs and special skills. The co-operative play is, if anything, even more entertaining than single player, especially as summoned friends can progress anywhere in the game without artificial boundaries being set, and can even (if their faith is strong enough) revive their partners. Finally, the NG+ system creates a fresh level of challenge for players who have beaten the regular game, significantly upping enemy health and damage output.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Holy Sh*t, this game... You try it for the first few minutes and you instantly fall in love with it.Salt and Sanctuary is basicly a game inspired by darksouls, But in 2D. The gameplay works the same: Be reckless, you get â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed over, Instead of souls, you have Salt and you spend those to level up and upgrade your gear.But compared to darksouls, this game stands out on it's own very easyly; Gameplay wise, it's rather different since it's a 2D game, the atmosphere feels claustrophobic once you enter in rooms, sometime in total darkness wich forces you to use up torches to see in the dark or to equip something that will give you a few hits of what's happening around you. Another huge feature of the game is the skill tree. In this skill tree, you start somewhere different depending of wich class you choose at the begining. the left side of the tree is mostely Oriented toward spells, sightly over it, Daggers, then swords, Hammers and so forth. Each point spent in the tree gives you stats that will help you toward  choosing your playstyle.For exeple; if you want to do a knight, you'll probably go to the top left where the tree have alot of STR upgrades, It's also where you'll find the skill required to weild better swords (Weapons range from level 0 to 4.) And along the way, you could also reach in the Heavy armor mastery skill along with shields, and some upgrades to your stamina and carry weight to be more efficient in close combat.Another similar thing to the darksouls is the fact that the world is one huge map, only difference is than instead of bonfires, you have Altars, where you can praise an entity. (Little tip; depending of your awnser at the begining of the game with the first NPC, you can actuly get different entity.) And in this altar, you can donate idols wich will spawn an NPC that will aid you in your journey (Merchant, Blacksmith, traveler...) Another thing is that if you get in an aleready claimed altar, you can level up like normal but cant donate  anything unless you join them.  though some NPCs might not apreciate it... Another thing that's different from darksouls is the curency. Yes it has salt. but it also have Gold. Gold is used to buy things from NPCs. Meaning that you don't have to worry about farming up as much souls to get the gears  and items that you want. Though, if you die, you loose a good 10% (I think it's 10%, from what I experienced.) of what you acumulated so far.So yeah. This is a basic summary of what the game is like.Pros: +Challenging+Looks realy smooth, The animations on the characters and enemy are realy satisfying to watch+The game ambiance is very well detailed and imersive.+Alots of variety in the class you'd like to play+Controls very well with a keyboard (No clue about controler.)+Enemys and bosses are fun to fight against...Cons:-...But some bosses are ridiculously easy if you have a good shield. Only exception are the ones that deals elemental damage.-I got lost. Alot. The game isnt holding your hand at all to show you where to go, wich is a bad but also a good thing since it encourages you to explore.-The platformings sections with certain enemys shooting you at a distance can be pretty anoying.Final note: 8.5/10 . The game is realy great, specialy if you love the souls series. Most players that liked those will get familiar with the game very quickly, and it's friendly enough to let new players play it without worrying too much.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												From the screenshots, I was expecting 2D Dark Souls - as the comparison is obvious. Surprisingly, what I played was a deepy involving experience, filled with adventure, constant danger, and fast paced, viceral combat. Salt and Sanctuary takes inspiration from the Souls series and flips it, incorporating Metroidvania elements across many beautiful environments. The design of the level builds the tension of exploration brilliantly, and the dramatic bosses and deadly monsters only increase it more - though, occasionally I found myself longing for more enemy variety. Often, you will fight smaller monsters, many of whom act and attack similarly; though this is minor complaint, as the variation of the larger monsters breaks this up immensely.The weapons feel fantastic to use, and the armour looks amazing. That said, for most of the game, what looked the best is what I used; armour values didn't seem to matter greatly. My only real major complaint is that many of the bosses relyed heavily on fire based attacks, meaning that to pass them, I would be required to stack fire resistance items, and that is all. This happened many times, certainly more than the other elements, and I saw little variation in other bosses elemental attacks.Still, Salt and Sanctuary is a finely crafted game - one that I will certainly play again. These minor issues don't compare to the sense of wonder and curiosity that this game gave me, and I am glad to have purchased it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I still haven't finished the game and I got it shortly after release.  It is a solid platformer with satisfying, yet difficult combat.  The length of the game is plenty and there is all sorts of secrets and loot to discover.  I had a hard time going back to this game because it came out the week before Dark Souls 3 and it just doesn't compare.  The co-op gameplay is really fun and was implemented quite well. If you like challenging platformers and skill-based combat systems, you will enjoy this game.  It is deceptively deep and feels more like a Castlevania title than a typical left-to-right side-scrolling experience.  There is a HUGE skill tree and lots of ways to customize your character/build.  I like my pumpkin helmet.  I'm the type of Steam user that collects games but only finish my favorites.  It kind of feels like playing a Zelda game on a game boy after playing Twilight Princess, it's still a great experience but doesn't compare to similar AAA titles.  Since I plan to finish it someday soon, I think I would give it a 4/5.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26
												A rather brilliant Metroidvania homage to Soulsborne.Sweet- Satisfying combat that rewards careful planning- Environments look wonderful and obviously a lot of effort has gone into the world design- Loads of enemy variety to keep things fresh throughout- Loads of great, memorable boss battles with some lovecraftian influences- Interesting character progression system that's flexibile enough to allow for some creative build design- Lots of playstyle variety with loads of magic to choose from as well as distinct melee and ranged weapon types- For the most part, the controls are fluid and responsive- Creed system adds a nice layer of personal world development and customisation- Great atmosphere and some interesting loreSalty- There's no inventory management and no external storage, so inventory becomes cluttered and unmanageable- Soundtrack is very limited which seems a bit of a diservice to the large environment, enemy and boss variety- Some enemies need some functionality changed. In particular the teleporting skeletons are a bit ridiculous and just frustrate rather than challenge. I actually thought this was bugged at first.- An online multiplayer would have been niceApart from those few small annoyances I thoroughly enjoyed everything on offer and I'm impressed with the quality of the experience from such a small development team. I'd certainly absorb a sequel or a spiritual successor.

Posted: October 27, 2016
												Recommended with caveats. Like Dark Souls 2, this is a deeply flawed game that yet manages to be entertaining. Primary irritations include:Â· enemies that spawn on top of you with no way to detect or affect them beforehandÂ· death causing an enemy to appear that, though weak, drains your entire stamina bar if you try to block it and can kill you quickly, even if you don't care about the damn saltÂ·Â little explanation of mechanics (much like Dark Souls, in a bad way)Â· there's a LOT of platforming, and while it's better than any DS platforming, it often requires too-precise jumpsÂ· poorly lit areasÂ·Â unattractive art, but that's a personal thingThese issues get really bad in the swamp, and I'm honestly halfassing my play at this point, because it's tedious to retry it for the 20th time after slightly mistiming a jump and dying. Watching a stream is more entertaining.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Salt & Sanctuary does a lot of things Dark Souls did right, with it's own unique twist. The 2D environment gave it it's own unique difficulty with the platforming traps. The skill system is, IMO, a much better system than DS's simple stat levelling, offering the ability to make a truly unique character for every playthrough. The fact that an average playthrough doesn't take that much time also helps with replayability.Overall a very fun romp and a very nice surprise from the indie scene. I really hope they make a sequel with more weapon variety.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Basically a Castlevania + Dark Souls hybrid. Difficult, but mostly fair. If I had to put up a complaint, it would be that sometimes enemies can patrol off-screen or between areas, but still hit you while you have no real way to retaliate. It doesn't happen that often, though. There's a skill tree system, which allows you to develop your character how you please - it's very remniscent of Path of Exile, in that there are individual nodes that increase parameters, but you can reach another class' section of the tree if you so desired.The game will test your patience, so I recommend stepping away and coming back when you end up dying a lot. Definitely worth the buy, though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2
												Short of it: Mostly for people who like Souls games for the Souls games (with more metroidvania sprinkled in) and not the co-op/PvP. Not everyone will like it, but ehh.. who cares if they don't?Souls-like that unfortunately lacks online multiplayer, but you can still couch co-op and optionally even PvP with your friend if you really must. This is a simpler and more compressed experience with more Metroidvania inspirations than Souls games had and some features of its own. A little hit&miss for lovers of Souls style games due to the limitations of the multiplayer and other limitations, but if you don't look it as trying to be another proper Souls game (which it isn't, it's 2D for crying out loud), you can enjoy it perfectly.Unfortunately unlike Souls games, this one denies you from using gear you don't have unlocked the skill for, which is kinda nonsense, but it also sort of makes sense since your lacking stats in Souls games would soft block such things anyway.I've enjoyed it so far, lacking some hints where I can go in some parts, but I'm still trying to beat it. Kinda met a boss that my build is not as great for as it was for the ones before, but heyyyy, not like that isn't the norm in Souls games with gimmick builds :p

												This is by far one of the best games I've played this year. Just saying it's a 2D Dark Souls clone doesn't do the game justice. It definitely straight up copies most of Dark Souls best elements, but it does so expertly not mindlessly, and intermingles it with it's own rich lore and phenomenal Metroidvania style of exploration and plattforming.It's an incredibly atmospheric game, even after having played it through once it still gave me chills on subsequent playthroughs.It offers an insane amount of possible and effective character builds, far more than any of the aforementioned games.So if you enjoy games such as Dark Souls, Bloodborne, Metroid, Castlevania: SotN, you must play this game, it is easily just as good any of these classics.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7
												I purchased Salt and Sanctuary expecting another Dark Souls experience to tide me over until the next dlc for Dark Souls 3. What i recieved was a brutally unforgiving game with similair mechanics as Dark Souls, but 2D. Failing again and again it reminded me of the first time I played Dark Souls, and how engrossed I became into this one little game. The map design is brilliant for being just a 2D and the play style is refreshing compared to its 3D counterparts. As one would expect this game is rich in lore and story, but to truly understand it you must research on your own in the wikis and forums (just like Dark Souls). By the end of the first playthrough I felt very pleased and satisifed as I once was with the ending of the first Dark Souls. If you enjoy those types of games that make you rage and "gitgud", then this gem is for you.P.S. I never comment/review anything EVER, so this being my first I felt more people needed to learn and play this masterpiece :^)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5
												This is "Dark Souls" meets "Castlevania: Symphony of the Night".  The battle mechanics, gear upgrade system, character progression, lore presentation, grim-dark aesthetics, and the difficult-yet-fair game play are all there, but they are placed in a two-dimentional platformer environment.  The game isn't perfect, due to a few odd bugs here and there, but it's nothing game breaking.  With Salt and Sanctuary, these small budget indie developers have done something that the multi-million dollar "triple-A" gaming companies have been unable to do:  create a game that *feels* like it belongs in the Dark Souls game franchise, along with Demon's Soul and BloodBorne.  It's amazing, and well worth looking into if you are a fan of that series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7
												Pros: 1) Good Combat System - attacks flow together nicely and there is a sizeable variety of weapons2) Unique Bosses - there are a few that are a little similar but they usually force you to use varied stategies against them.3) Optional Bosses - Self explanatory4) interconnected world - all one map that has secret passages all over that allow you to move back to earlier areas easier5) Variety of Builds - from the quick light armored fighter, to the heavy armored warrior with a massive shield, down to spellcasters with a nice assortment of spellsCons:1) shift in art style from player character to enemies and environment (felt like mixing Salvador dali style art with something like the powerpuff girls)2) Iron Rampart a sheild that exists and counters nearly everything once you get it (takes a lot of strategy out of the game)3) Loss of 10% of current gold each time you die with no way to retrieve it. (this really limited the sense of exploration because it gave you an even greater punishment for dying) This becomes a problem later on in the game when the path forward isn't always clear. 4) Less skill based than dark souls, I think this is best shown as while you are blocking it blocks all sides rather than just the side the sheild is facing. 5) Storytelling - Lackluster storytelling, very little lore in game just item description that don't seem to come together very well.6) Punishing Rather than Challenging - Often this game had trap rooms without a warning which makes you learn through repetition rather than learning and overcoming the obstacles by stategy (seems to use memorization for a challenge rather than a difficult puzzel)7/10 worth a single playthough.

												Like what the 100 other reviews say, it's a  2d  Dark/Demon souls, that you can play local co op :D -  How it's alike you say? - It has the health/stamina/magic bar - bonfires aka "Sanctuarys".- There's Sorcery and Miracles- Stats on weapons/armors/character (like dex,strength,etc)- Covenants aka "Creeds"- Death equals = Bye bye Salt (Currency) and you have one chance to get it back- Difficulty- Plus More!  If you are a Dark/Demons Souls fan , I highly recommend you buy the game! 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												While the human character designs are rather poor, the monsters look great and the gameplay is a well balanced blend of Dark Souls and Metroid. Souls veterans may find it a bit on the easy side and the controller button layout is... rather confusing, but it's still a fun time.That being said, I will give one caveat to this recommendation. As you progress through the early midgame, we get two bosses in a row which are absolutely infuriating. The first is called "the tree of men" and it combines a lot of ledge-grabbing at the very top of a jump (the most finicky control aspect in an otherwise tight game) with usually instant death if you fail. Then you get the "Disemboweled Husk" which is fine on his own. Challenging, sure. Aggressive, does a lot of damage, but fine. The problem is the run-back. The enemies are aranged so it's nearly impossible to avoid them as you would normally do in a run-back, so either you die or you fight them. But fighting them takes a while, because of the flying enemies that always float out of reach whenever you try to hit them and take really too many hits to kill. Basically what I'm saying is that, like Dark Souls, there are several parts of this game which are aggrevating due to poor design. However S&S has more of them, and they're more aggrevating. Still good overall but... there are a few serious black marks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												As someone who doesn't really like Dark Souls, all the constant comparisons to Dark Souls with this game really worried me. I primarily was looking at this game to play another Metroidvania type game, and thought a game on the more difficult side would be refreshing. Let me just say, this game is really great. The similarities to Dark Souls come mostly from the difficulty and leveling system, which is basically identical. But the 2D platforming and exploration parts of this game are truly excellent, and I've had a blast trying to find my way through the dark caves and the towns and everything in between. The game is really reminicent of old NES games where memory played a huge key. There are lots of traps that, should you run into them, may damage you significantly or even kill you. There are a lot of enemies that may die with one hit, but if you fail to see them, or mistime a swing of your sword, those enemies can kill you and you lose all your salt to level up. I really liked the emphasis on memory in combination with 2D platforming and exploration since it's exactly what I wanted this type of game to be. So, even if you're like me and don't really like Dark Souls, this game offers something for other people as well.

content:
Posted: January 9
												I never tried the souls games before, but as a Metroidvania fan I had to check out a 2D souls game since I sincerely believe Metroidvania and LoZ were the basis and inspiration for the souls games, but enough history lesson. Man am I loving this game, it's gorgeous from beginning to end (especially the end), the combat and controls are so tight and smooth, and the audio is just mesmerizing (including the music). It has all the respawning enemies/backtracking elements from Metroidvania/Souls games so there's never a dull moment. Simply put this is a game heavy with atmosphere, exploration, tight combat, and very fun lore, there's a little bit of platforming as well if that's your thing. If you like Souls or/and Metroidvania you will love this. 10/10, can't recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: January 7
												I purchased Salt and Sanctuary expecting another Dark Souls experience to tide me over until the next dlc for Dark Souls 3. What i recieved was a brutally unforgiving game with similair mechanics as Dark Souls, but 2D. Failing again and again it reminded me of the first time I played Dark Souls, and how engrossed I became into this one little game. The map design is brilliant for being just a 2D and the play style is refreshing compared to its 3D counterparts. As one would expect this game is rich in lore and story, but to truly understand it you must research on your own in the wikis and forums (just like Dark Souls). By the end of the first playthrough I felt very pleased and satisifed as I once was with the ending of the first Dark Souls. If you enjoy those types of games that make you rage and "gitgud", then this gem is for you.P.S. I never comment/review anything EVER, so this being my first I felt more people needed to learn and play this masterpiece :^)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16
												Salt and Sanctuary is a true tribute to the Souls series. Everything that makes the Souls games great is there and intact in 2d form, though there are other elements that resemble games such as Castlevania more. Therein, lies the root of the game's problems. A middling plot, a somewhat questionable art style, and some subpar design choices unfortunately mar the greatness of the game's vistas, sense of progression and variety, and absurdly tight and rewarding gameplay that'll just make you not want to put the game down until you've beaten it. Had this game been less -else, and more -souls, it would have been perfect in every sense. As it is, the pros more than outweigh the cons, and it's a must buy for fans of Dark Souls at any price range.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21
												If you are someone looking for a refreshing experience from the Souls style of game then Salt and Sanctuary is for you. Mixing the beloved Souls formula with 2D platforming and other elements, Salt and Sanctuary is a fantasic product that really rewards the player for their feats. If I did have a few major issues with this game is certain weapons and styles are obivous superior than others. I used a greatsword for the majority of the game and simple flew past many of the bosses. Another big issue is although the game looks really good and is impressive at times, it often blends together. Many maps loop back into one another like Dark Souls 1 but the areas end up look so similar at times I could not name where I was without trouble. It's not that big of a deal but it's very noticable when you play long enough. The Challenge of the game is so and so as well. Sometimes I question if the boss I fought was really a boss while other times I wondered why it was so difficult. Witch of the Lake and The tree fire-spraying boss are great examples of this. The platforming is okay and it's only when you get the power-ups that the platform is actually fun and it becomes easy to travel. Overall if your looking for a Dark Souls game that is close to Dark Souls 1 while shaking things up, Salt and Sanctuary is the game for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17
												An amazing tribute to the Souls genre and a worthy addition to that pantheon. It understands the fundamentals that makes Dark Souls great and respects them.It also adds it's own twists, this isn't a ripoff or a clone but an inspired production+ Combat that blends deliberate stamina-based combat with combos and skills+ Freeform playstyle, switch easily between weapons and styles to suit your needs+ Nightmarish, interconnected world. Superbly done and easily comparable to any Metroid-vania+ Implicit storytelling reveals a deep and mysterious world, look up The Drowned Tome for lore explanation ~Dodges can be a bit difficult to judge, and can result in some annoying deaths, but it isn't a major issue and you eventually get the hang of it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Salt and Sanctuary is a very well made platformer, which many people claim to be a dark souls in 2D. While it sports some elements dark souls fans will find familiar it does add its own touches to mechanincs and gameplay. The map design is amazing and the areas are interconnected very cleverly, while the combat is brutal and fast , and it feels great too annihilate your enemies in a spray of limbs and red liquid :D. There are also a lot of different options to play your character so this game also offers a high replayability. The only weak point i would mention is the music. while i liked it, there could certainly have been more variety in the boss fight themes.If you're a player who's into dark souls and metroidvanias you should definitely buy this game. At first i was a bit sceptical about the price but in the end it was worth every penny.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13
												20 hours in, at the time of this review. Yep, there are a lot of comparisons to Dark Souls. Replace souls with salt, and it's basically the same mechanic. It's fair enough to say it is a Metroidvania Dark Souls. And this one did it amazingly. It's been a while since I've enjoyed a platformer of this nature.I put this one just below Symphony of the Night, in terms of 'Where did four hours just go? .... meh.... *tap* *tap* *tap*...There's an expansive skill tree, so few builds will feel exactly alike. Want a pole axe maniac mage? Have at it, Brochacho! You can do eet!The crafting system isn't terribly deep, but it's interesting. Bosses drop items which can be used to turn certain weapons into various stronger weapons. This can also be achieved with far more common items. It's neat.There's no actual pause. The only safe places are sanctuaries you must claim in the name of a number of idols which have their own benefits. You'll have to claim sanctuaries in their name and kill their enemies to improve these semi-customizable sanctuaries.You customize the sanctuaries by placing figures (cleric, fighter, leader, traveler, merchant, blacksmith, etc.) upon the altar of your chosen idol. The traveler in particular makes getting around the world easier, via an item he sells. Fast travel, gold is cheap!Another thing I love about this game is that you can farm all you want and get totally OP. But you can still easily die if you forget about the various ambush situations throughout the game. Try being level 80, repeatedly without cancel, getting smacked around by an unfortunately effective sneak attack.Now go back and git gud. Git u salt. Git rekd old man.Git this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9
												Amazing game.I had the itch to play DS3 again after the DLCs came out but didn't really want to go back to the grind. Enter S&S. All the things that make these games ("castlevania-like" or "souls-like") great, with some great weapons / attack combos, dense level design, some tough bosses (until you have a STR / hammer or greatsword build, which is OP for the first several bosses), awesome visual style, very forgiving movement and, this is the best part, can run on old hardware or laptops. I was pleasantly surprised to get the game 30-40fps on a 4 year old i5-3317u with an HD4000 (integrated graphics only. Which means I get to play this at work.I'd say this is much more accessible than anything in the Dark Souls series, so worth a shot for players not used to those games.Don't know what keyboard controls are like, but with a 360 controller it's great.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												A spectacular adaptation of Dark Souls to two dimensions. Captures every aspect that made DS great - the skillful combat, the oppressive atmosphere, the variety of playstyles, the rewarding exploration, the hidden lore. On top of all that, it adds platforming challenges to the mix. Well, Dark Souls had those too, but this time the controls are actually suited to them.The only flaw I found was uneven difficulty - it's easy to find a build so powerful that bosses become trivial about a third of the way through the game. If you end up breezing through it, definitely try New Game +, as the difficulty curve will catch up to you and give you a much better challenge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Basically a Castlevania + Dark Souls hybrid. Difficult, but mostly fair. If I had to put up a complaint, it would be that sometimes enemies can patrol off-screen or between areas, but still hit you while you have no real way to retaliate. It doesn't happen that often, though. There's a skill tree system, which allows you to develop your character how you please - it's very remniscent of Path of Exile, in that there are individual nodes that increase parameters, but you can reach another class' section of the tree if you so desired.The game will test your patience, so I recommend stepping away and coming back when you end up dying a lot. Definitely worth the buy, though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13
												Ah man. Where to even start with this game. I guess with the obvious, in that it definitely takes a lot from the Souls series. But holy crap, it takes everything it can, makes it 2D, and then makes it work fantastically.  The Good Stuff:   The controls are TIGHT. Everything feels damn good. I will say I play this with a controller primarily, but from the couple times I've tried on the keyboard, it felt good there too. The jump button will still be your nemesis, but DAMN does this play well. It's exactly as precise and responsive as you would want in a 2D platformer.  The game stays true to the Souls series in being punishing for bad play. This is a game you're gonna have to get good at, as with any other soulsborne game. You're going to be hard pressed to cheese through anything, especially on your first playthrough. But when you git gud? You feel incredible. It's super satisfying to finally beat that boss that's been giving you trouble for the past couple hours.  The art style is incredible, or maybe I have a soft spot for it. I was previously a fan of the nitty-gritty disproportioned look of The Dishwasher: Dead Samurai (from the same developer, if you're not following my thought process here), so perhaps this will not appeal to all those who stumble across this game. That said, the environments are beautiful, and the bosses are freaky. The art style definitely grants a lot to this game.  The progression through the game is steady, and flows incredibly well. At least in my experience, I never felt like I wandered to the "wrong" place, or that a detour I took was "too far out of the way" or anything. In fact, exploring a little bit out of the way (or into an area you're not as prepared for) can sometimes pay off through some easy-to-acquire loot to give you a little bit of an edge.The Meh:There's not much to put here, but I have one thing to point out. I might add to here if things cross my mind later on down the line.  You can find certain areas to "powerlevel" in. I did find myself at two points in the game where I felt I just needed a little bit extra power to proceed, possibly due to previous fast progression or something. Either way, I found myself running out of a sanctuary, killing all nearby enemies, returning to the sanctuary to respawn the enemies, and repeating the process for a while to eek out some extra levels. I don't think this is detrimental to the game, as it could have been just because of my playstyle, but I feel the need to mention it here. During those times it felt grindy, obviously, but I don't think it detracted from the gameplay enough to warrant distaste in it.The Bad:  There's no map. That's literally the only downside I can think of. You're going to just want to pull up the wiki at least for the map. Other than that, I can't fault this game for anything else.The Final Verdict:If you like the soulsborne series, you're going to love this. If you think you'll like the soulsborne-style game, you'll love this. Hell, if you just love 2D platformers with good combat mechanics, you'll probably love this as well. It's just that good. It's worth the regular price, and it's a damn steal at anything less than that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Salt and Sanctuary is an homage to the Souls franchise that has been the mainstay of From Software since Demon's Souls was released back in 2009. This game is a throwback to the first two titles in the series, borrowing several concepts regarding combat and exploration from those titles. The way in which you heal, dodge, increase in strength and chain actions together, though in 2D rather than 3D, is very reminiscent of the mechanics from these titles and all of this is executed in a tight and predictable manner. Best of all, most of the first play-through is beatable without wearing armor or performing heavy upgrades to weapons, so most of the content is almost entirely skill based. If you know how to play the game, you can get through it without feeling like there is a hard gear check for most of the game.Where Salt and Sanctuary actually shines is in the original ideas it brings to the table. This game makes incredible use of vertical stacking akin to the 2D Metroid games, but uses it as more of a way to represent distance between areas rather than them literally being physically above or below one another. It has an excellent array of areas and bosses, each which follow different principles and have extremely varied weaknesses and strengths. There are bosses that follow traditional duck and swing, sword and board as well as keep away principles of Souls fame. There are also bosses which follow 2D fighting game principles where combos, rushdowns, grabs, cross-ups and dizzying the opponent are all important concepts. The variety of weapons and spells in the game is just enough to entice you to try playing the game in each possible manner and keep the same challenges entertaining for several play-throughs. The game also has a few challenging platforming segments and principles that cause you to look and travel the world completely differently each time you discover a new one. This totally changes the incentives and how you look at the architecture you come across, and like any good Metroid environment, causes you to rethink things you already wandered past.The music and the sound are all crisp and convincing as well. Other than the rudimentary character faces, there's really nothing in this game that is not beautiful and pleasing to the eye in the environments or the enemy designs. You can tell that this game borrows from many other games and fantasy settings than just the Souls series in the types of dungeons and enemies you trek through and are put up against. All in all, no transition is soo harsh or bizzare that it seems not to fit. Because of this, the world the game takes place in is very believable and interesting. I often forget how pleasing the aesthetics are and I'm always impressed when I come back to the game and remind myself.If you enjoy adventure games with hard bosses and very few hints, are a fan of the Souls series or the original Zelda, or are just looking for a dungeon or horror game of medium difficulty to start you off on the genre, Salt and Sanctuary is a definite must. You will enjoy what this game has to offer.

Dark Souls had this promise too but they never kept it.-Skill progression with a huge talent tree like in Final Fantasy 10 or Path of Exile, very well made-YOU CAN CAST SPELLS MIDAIR AND YOUR GUY DOES LIKE A SLOW MOTION MATRIX THINGWeaker than Dark Souls:-No invasions-No voices-Weapons got sick movesets with air combos but still not as rich as in Dark Souls.-casting a lightning spell may require you to buy new headphones. 												Five Word Review: 2D Dark Souls, great game.Favorite Thing: It thoroughly scratched my Dark Souls itch. Lots of challenging bosses and level design that goes everywhere.Least Favorite Thing: There's an over-reliance on darkness. A lot of the time the majority of the screen is extremely dark or completely black. On a separate note, variety for mage spells and gear are extremely lacking.Playtime: ~ 28h (explored everything I could find)Enjoyment: 9/10Recommendation: If you enjoyed Dark Souls, definitely.

Posted: March 2
												Lots of comparisons to Dark Souls, in that it is hard, but I'd put it closer to a difficult Metroidvania type. I'd say it's a lot easier to get a hang of than Dark Souls, and there are fewer bosses that trouble most average players in S&S than DS. That being said, it was loads of fun once I got over the initial hump, only wish there was more replay value in NG+ other than maxxing out your skills tree. The art is well done and the atmosphere is creepy. For a bargain price, this is well worth the investment.

content:
Posted: March 4
												I have tried out a few different classes, and I've beaten the game twice now. I've never really played the Dark Souls franchise much, so I don't know if that's what I ought to be comparing this to. I can however say that this game is (mostly) as fair as it is punishing. Failure sucks, but sticking it out is more satisfying because of that. The thing I don't like about this game? Platforming and jumping "puzzles." I have no interest in Parkour in my RPG to the degree which this game has it in certain areas. If you are looking for a neat little RPG to have fun with, I highly recommend getting this on sale. The local co-op in Salt and Sanctuary is also pretty good, even if there are occasional camera issues.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 21
												I do not like 2D games.I like this game.This game gets my approval.But seriously this is a difficult, yet rewarding game to play. The first 3 bosses gave me trouble and the others I killed on the first try because of what I learned in the previous fights. It also helped that I more than doubled the damage on my weapon :PLots of people compare this to Dark Souls, and yes it has a few things similar to it, but the gameplay is very different in my opinion. Specially the 2D aspect of it makes dodging a lot more difficult and the enemies here can attack at average speed or lightning quick. There is no room for mistakes here, specially early on when healing is limited. This brings me to the last thing I want to mention from my first impression: The skill tree. Oh my oh my it felt overwhelming at first, but then I realized it was rather simple. I just had to find the final node I wanted and trace it back down towards the center and then I realized I could reach class 5/5 swordfighter within the first 5 hours of the game if I wanted to. This actually feels great. It doesn't take too long to get anywhere but of course it gets more expensive as it goes on. There's truly so much freedom in how you build your character and I love it. It's essentially a simpler version of what path of exile uses and that is a great thing.Alright I'm ready with some cons for this game:-some enemies leave no time for healing between attacking/getting staggered at all. I do consider this a flaw in games that are about the combat-some bosses have uneven models and don't turn around their center, which severely changes their hitbox in a split second. This is very poor design in my opinion-the game can easily be beaten before you can wear a full set of class 4 armor due to its weight/endurance problems :(With how cheap the game is, you just can't go wrong though. I'm rating it based on what it is regardless of price and I say this game scores no less than 8/10.
